'''Lefty Bates''' (March 9, 1920 – April 7, 2007)<ref name="Dead">"Rock, Doc" (2007). [http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2007.html "The Dead Rock Stars Club 2007 January to June"]. thedeadrockstarsclub.com. Accessed October 13, 2011]</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] guitarist. He led the Lefty Bates Combo, and variously worked with [[the El Dorados]], [[the Flamingos]], [[Jimmy Reed]], [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Buddy Guy]], [[Etta James]], the Aristo-Kats, the Hi-De-Ho Boys, the Moroccos, and [[the Impressions]].<ref name="Dead"/> A regular on the Chicago blues scene, Bates major work was as a [[session musician]] on a multitude of recordings made in the 1950s and 1960s.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p54897|pure_url=yes}}|title=Lefty Bates |author=Eugene Chadbourne |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 13, 2011}}</ref>

Bates was married to well-known area club dancer Mary Cole Bates, who died in 2001.<ref name="CT">{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-04-19/news/0704180912_1_mr-bates-session-player-blues |title=William H. 'Lefty' Bates: 1920 - 2007 |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=April 19, 2007 |first=Trevor |last=Jensen |accessdate=2011-10-14}}</ref>

==Biography==
He was born '''William Bates''' in [[Leighton, Alabama]], [[United States]], and acquired his [[nickname]] from his [[left-handed]] guitar playing.<ref name="Dead"/> Bates was raised in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], attending [[Vashon High School]] and while there help form the Hi-De-Ho Boys.<ref name="Hubcap">{{cite web |url=http://hubcap.clemson.edu/~campber/club51.html |title=The Club 51 Label |author=Robert Pruter and Robert L. Campbell |date= |work= |publisher=Hubcap.clemson.edu |accessdate=October 13, 2011}}</ref> In 1936, they relocated to [[Chicago]], and recorded for [[Decca Records]] and played in several Chicago clubs.  Bates served in [[World War II]], and later joined the Aristo-Kats, who recorded on [[RCA Records|RCA Victor]].<ref name="AMG"/>

Bates formed his own [[musical ensemble|ensemble]] with [[Quinn Wilson]], and they played locally through most of the 1950s.  The ensemble's few recordings were issued by [[United Records|United]], Boxer, Mad and Apex Records under Bates name. The majority of Bates' paid work came from regular club work and as a [[session musician]], most notably as the [[rhythm guitarist]] with both [[Jimmy Reed]] and [[Buddy Guy]].<ref name="AMG"/> He undertook other work with [[Larry Birdsong]] and Honey Brown. His versatility led to employment as part of the [[recording studio|studio]] band for [[Vee-Jay Records]], alongside [[Red Holloway]] and [[Vernel Fournier]] amongst others.<ref name="Hubcap"/> The bulk of the musicians there had also worked earlier for [[Chance Records]], backing both [[Jimmy Reed]] and [[The Spaniels]]. Vee-Jay's financial strength helped them survive, and their studio band was expected to back a diversity of musicians on an ''ad hoc'' basis, including [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]], [[blues]], [[jazz]] and [[doo-wop]] artists.<ref name="AMG"/> In 1955, [[the El Dorados]] found national success with "At My Front Door", on which Bates played guitar, and which peaked at number one on the [[United States|U.S]], ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= Robert
| last= Pruter
| year= 1996
| title= Doo-wop: the Chicago scene
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of Illinois Press
| location= Champaign, Illinois
| isbn= 0-252-02208-4
| page= 113}}</ref><ref name="whitburnr&b">{{cite book |title= Top R&B/Hip-Hop Singles: 1942-1995|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=1996 |publisher=Record Research |page=133}}</ref>

From 1955, Bates worked in a similar manner with another Chicago-based record label, Club 51,<ref name="Hubcap"/> although there he had the luxury of leading "The Lefty Bates Orchestra". At Club 51 he backed The Five Buddies and [[Sunnyland Slim]].<ref name="AMG"/> In 1957, Bates along with [[Earl Hooker]], backed the singer [[Arbee Stidham]], on his recording of "Look Me Straight in the Eye".<ref>{{cite book
| first= Sebastian
| last= Danchin
| year= 2001
| title= Earl Hooker, blues master
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University Press of Mississippi
| location= Jackson, Mississippi
| isbn= 1-57806-306-X
| page= 108
| url=http://books.google.com/books?id=-G76U3ikkFAC&pg=PA108#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>

In 1959, Bates played with Reed on his recording of "[[Baby What You Want Me to Do]]". By March 1960, Bates was part of the backing trio for [[John Lee Hooker]] on his [[album]], ''Travellin'''.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Ted
| last= Gioia
| year= 2008
| title= Delta Blues: The Life and Times of the Mississippi Masters Who Revolutionized American Music
| edition= 1st
| publisher= W.W. Norton & Company Inc.
| location= New York
| isbn= 978-0-393-06258-8
| page= 257
|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=i0yjZiHcS6MC&pg=PA257#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>  In 1961, Bates appeared on ''[[Jimmy Reed at Carnegie Hall]]'', plus in the same year played on Reed's recording of "[[Big Boss Man (song)|Big Boss Man]]".

Bates died of an [[arteriosclerosis]] in Chicago in April 2007, aged 87.<ref name="Dead"/>
